primaryItems.caption: Corner of New Mill House and Forebay from Forebay Bridge, 1895

secondaryItems.name: HC1
secondaryItems.caption: Passenger Steamboats made regular schedules runs between the Fairmount Water Works and locations upstream, as well as scheduled and chartered siteseeing trips. c.1885
secondaryItems.credit: Photo Courtesy of Robert N. Dennis Collection, New York Public Library

secondaryItems.name: HC2
secondaryItems.caption: Fairmount from the Outer Forebay. Crest of Fairmount Reservoir, initially constructed 1815. Demolished in 1919 to make way for the Philadelphia Museum of Art. c.1875
secondaryItems.credit: Photo Courtesy of Fairmount Water Works Recording Project, HAER, 1978, Library of Congress

secondaryItems.name: HC3
secondaryItems.credit: Children at foot of North Cliffside Path, c.1900
secondaryItems.caption: Photo Courtesy of Robert N. Dennis Collection, New York Public Library

historicContext.text: For foreign and native travelers in the nineteenth century making the grand tour of the United States it was unthinkable to be in Philadelphia without visiting the Fairmount Water Works on the banks of the Schuylkill River.
